title.value: Protective effectiveness of previous SARS-CoV-2 infection and hybrid immunity against the omicron variant and severe disease: a systematic review and meta-regression
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Protective effectiveness of previous SARS-CoV-2 infection and hybrid immunity against the omicron variant and severe disease: a systematic review and meta-regression

extractions.description: This paper systematically reviews and conducts a meta-regression analysis to assess the protective effectiveness of previous SARS-CoV-2 infection and hybrid immunity (combination of infection and vaccination) against the omicron variant and severe disease. The study examines the magnitude and duration of this protection.

type.justification: The study involves systematic review and meta-regression analyses, which are empirical research methodologies aimed at synthesizing data from multiple studies to estimate effects.
type.quote: Methods For this systematic review and meta-regression, we searched for cohort, cross-sectional, and caseâ€“control studies in MEDLINE, Embase, Web of Science...We used log-odds random-effects meta-regression to estimate the magnitude of protection at 1-month intervals.

name.justification: The study focuses on understanding the spread and protection mechanisms against a specific variant of SARS-CoV-2 at a population level, a core aspect of epidemiology.
name.quote: Restricting the spread of SARS-CoV-2 infection and preventing severe COVID-19 remains a priority at the global scale.

name.justification: The paper discusses the protective effects of vaccinations and hybrid immunity, which is central to the study of vaccinology.
name.quote: Previous SARS-CoV-2 infection and hybrid immunity both provided greater and more sustained protection against the omicron variant than vaccination alone.
